message.content:
In the manufacturing process, quality control (QC) means ensuring that products meet their intended specifications and standards by monitoring all production stages. Manufacturers put in place a series of tests, checks, and measurements to evaluate product performance before releasing it to end-users.

During the QC stage, different teams ensure that:

1. Raw materials selection: The starting point is choosing high-quality raw materials or parts which meet established requirements.
 
2. Quality inspection procedures: Inspectors apply strict guidelines for detecting defects at various checkpoints throughout the production line.

3. In-process inspections: At each step of production, workers follow standard operation procedures (SOPs) and test samples against benchmarks to prevent errors from passing on to subsequent processes.

4. Testing final goods: Inspectors examine completed batches or individual items applying non-destructive testing methods like visual inspections or electronic systems designed specifically for defect detection in products like microchips.

5. Maintaining records of results: QCs measurement data and reports can be timely reviewed for better decision making about future adjustments related to improvement work tasks required during ongoing productions because this proactive approach will help identify problem areas more quickly than solely relying on spot-checking finished products after completion sent off delivery trucks finally reach customer destinations worldwide orbit>.
